metadata.title: Australian Government Information Security manual
metadata.remarks:
This is not an official version of the Australian Government Information Security Manual.

Find the official versions here: https://www.cyber.gov.au/acsc/view-all-content/ism
This content was generated using scrips/ISM/ISM.py

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A system administration process, with supporting system administration procedures, is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Privileged users use a dedicated administrator workstation when performing privileged tasks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Privileged users are assigned an unprivileged administration account for authenticating to their dedicated administrator workstations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Dedicated administrator workstations used for privileged tasks are prevented from communicating to assets not related to administrative activities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All administrative infrastructure including, but not limited to, administrator workstations and jump servers are hardened.

controls.title: Dedicated administration zones and communication restrictions

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Administrator workstations are placed into a separate network zone to user workstations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Management traffic is only allowed to originate from network zones that are used to administer systems and applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All administrative actions are conducted through a jump server.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Jump servers are prevented from communicating to assets and sending and receiving traffic not related to administrative activities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A change management process, and supporting change management procedures, is developed and implemented covering:
• identification and documentation of requests for change
• approval required for changes to be made
• assessment of potential security impacts
• notification of any planned disruptions or outages
• implementation and testing of approved changes
• the maintenance of system and security documentation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A patch management process, and supporting patch management procedures, is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A software register, including versions and patch histories of applications, drivers, operating systems and firmware for workstations, servers, mobile devices, network devices and all other ICT equipment, is maintained and regularly audited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security vulnerabilities in applications and drivers assessed as extreme risk are patched, updated or mitigated within 48 hours of the security vulnerabilities being identified by vendors, independent third parties, system managers or users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security vulnerabilities in applications and drivers assessed as high risk are patched, updated or mitigated within two weeks of the security vulnerability being identified by vendors, independent third parties, system managers or users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security vulnerabilities in applications and drivers assessed as moderate or low risk are patched, updated or mitigated within one month of the security vulnerability being identified by vendors, independent third parties, system managers or users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security vulnerabilities in operating systems and firmware assessed as extreme risk are patched, updated or mitigated within 48 hours of the security vulnerabilities being identified by vendors, independent third parties, system managers or users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security vulnerabilities in operating systems and firmware assessed as high risk are patched, updated or mitigated within two weeks of the security vulnerability being identified by vendors, independent third parties, system managers or users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security vulnerabilities in operating systems and firmware assessed as moderate or low risk are patched, updated or mitigated within one month of the security vulnerability being identified by vendors, independent third parties, system managers or users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: High assurance ICT equipment is only patched with patches approved by the ACSC using methods and timeframes prescribed by the ACSC.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A centralised and managed approach is used to patch or update applications and drivers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An approach for patching or updating applications and drivers that ensures the integrity and authenticity of patches or updates, as well as the processes used to apply them, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An automated mechanism is used to confirm and record that deployed application and driver patches or updates have been installed, applied successfully and remain in place.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A centralised and managed approach is used to patch or update operating systems and firmware.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An approach for patching or updating operating systems and firmware that ensures the integrity and authenticity of patches or updates, as well as the processes used to apply them, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An automated mechanism is used to confirm and record that deployed operating system and firmware patches or updates have been installed, applied successfully and remain in place.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Applications that are no longer supported by vendors with patches or updates for security vulnerabilities are updated or replaced with vendor-supported versions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Operating systems for workstations, servers and ICT equipment that are no longer supported by vendors with patches or updates for security vulnerabilities are updated or replaced with vendor-supported versions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A digital preservation policy is developed and implemented.

controls.title: Data backup and restoration processes and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A data backup process, and supporting data backup procedures, is developed and implemented.

controls.title: Data backup and restoration processes and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A data restoration process, and supporting data restoration procedures, is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backups of important information, software and configuration settings are performed at least daily.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backups are stored offline, or online but in a non-rewritable and non-erasable manner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backups are stored at a multiple geographically-dispersed locations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backups are stored for three months or greater.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Full restoration of backups is tested at least once when initially implemented and each time fundamental information technology infrastructure changes occur.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Partial restoration of backups is tested on a quarterly or more frequent basis.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated firewall is used between official or classified networks and public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated firewall is used between networks belonging to different security domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The requirement to use a firewall as part of gateway infrastructure is met by both parties independently; shared ICT equipment does not satisfy the requirements of both parties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition to the firewall between networks of different security domains, an evaluated firewall is used between an AUSTEO or AGAO network and a foreign network.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition to the firewall between networks of different security domains, an evaluated firewall is used between an AUSTEO or AGAO network and another Australian controlled network.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All systems are protected from systems in other security domains by one or more gateways.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All connections between security domains implement mechanisms to inspect and filter data flows for the transport and higher layers as defined in the OSI model.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Gateways:
• are the only communications paths into and out of internal networks
• allow only explicitly authorised connections
• are managed via a secure path isolated from all connected networks (physically at the gateway or on a dedicated administration network)
• log all physical and logical access to their components
• are configured to save logs to a secure logging facility
• have all security controls tested to verify their effectiveness after any changes to their configuration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Gateways implement ingress traffic filtering to detect and prevent Internet Protocol (IP) source address spoofing.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
All gateways connecting networks in different security domains are operated such that they:
• log network traffic permitted through the gateway
• log network traffic attempting to leave the gateway
• are configured to save event logs to a secure logging facility
• provide real-time alerts for any cyber security incidents, attempted intrusions and unusual usage patterns.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Demilitarised zones are used to broker access to services accessed by external entities, and mechanisms are applied to mediate internal and external access to less-trusted services hosted in these demilitarised zones.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Gateways are subject to rigorous testing, performed at irregular intervals no more than six months apart, to determine the strength of security controls.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to gateway administration functions is limited to the minimum roles and privileges to support the gateway securely.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System administrators are formally trained to manage gateways.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All system administrators of gateways are cleared to access the highest level of information communicated or processed by the gateway.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All system administrators of gateways that process Australian Eyes Only (AUSTEO) or Australian Government Access Only (AGAO) information are Australian nationals.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Roles for the administration of gateways are separated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For gateways between networks in different security domains, a formal arrangement exists whereby any shared components are managed by the system managers of the highest security domain or by a mutually agreed third party.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Once connectivity is established, system owners become information stakeholders for all connected security domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users and services accessing networks through gateways are authenticated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only users and services authenticated and authorised to a gateway can use the gateway.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used for access to gateways.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment accessing networks through gateways is authenticated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated diode is used for controlling the data flow of unidirectional gateways between official or classified networks and public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A high assurance diode is used for controlling the data flow of unidirectional gateways between classified networks and public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated diode is used for controlling the data flow of unidirectional gateways between official and classified networks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A high assurance diode is used for controlling the data flow of unidirectional gateways between official or classified networks where the highest system is SECRET or above.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated diode is used between an AUSTEO or AGAO network and a foreign network at the same classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated diode is used between an AUSTEO or AGAO network and another Australian controlled network at the same classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A diode (or server connected to the diode) deployed to control data flow in unidirectional gateways monitors the volume of the data being transferred.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When importing data into a security domain, by any means including a CDS, the data is filtered by a content filter designed for that purpose.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Content filters deployed in a CDS are subject to rigorous security assessment to ensure they mitigate content-based threats and cannot be bypassed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All suspicious, malicious and active content is blocked from entering a security domain.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any data identified by a content filtering process as suspicious is blocked until reviewed and approved for transfer by a trusted source other than the originator.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Email and web content entering a security domain is automatically run in a dynamic malware analysis sandbox to detect suspicious behaviour.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Content validation is performed on all data passing through a content filter with content which fails content validation blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Content conversion is performed for all ingress or egress data transiting a security domain boundary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Content sanitisation is performed on suitable file types if content conversion is not appropriate for data transiting a security domain boundary.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Antivirus scanning, using multiple different scanning engines, is performed on all content.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The contents from archive/container files are extracted and subjected to content filter checks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Controlled inspection of archive/container files is performed to ensure that content filter performance or availability is not adversely affected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Files that cannot be inspected are blocked and generate an alert or notification.

controls.title: Allowing access to specific content types

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A list of allowed content types is implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The integrity of content is verified where applicable and blocked if verification fails.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If data is signed, the signature is validated before the data is exported.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All encrypted content, traffic and data is decrypted and inspected to allow content filtering.

controls.title: When to implement a Cross Domain Solution

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When connecting a highly classified network to any other network from a different security domain, a CDS is implemented.

controls.title: Consultation when implementing or modifying a Cross Domain Solution

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When designing and deploying a CDS, the ACSC is notified and consulted; and directions provided by the ACSC are complied with.

controls.title: Consultation when implementing or modifying a Cross Domain Solution

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When introducing additional connectivity to a CDS, such as adding a new gateway to a common network, the ACSC is consulted on the impact to the security of the CDS; and directions provided by the ACSC are complied with.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CDS between a highly classified network and any other network implements isolated upward and downward network paths.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CDS between a highly classified network and any other network implements protocol breaks at each layer of the OSI model.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CDS between a highly classified network and any other network implements content filtering and separate independent security-enforcing components for upward and downward data flows.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All security-relevant events generated by a CDS are logged and regularly analysed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A representative sample of security events generated by a CDS, relating to the enforcement of data transfer policies, is taken at least every 3 months and assessed against the security policies that the CDS is responsible for enforcing between security domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users are trained on the secure use of a CDS before access to the CDS is granted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A web content filter is used to filter potentially harmful web-based content.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Client-side active content, such as Java, is restricted to a list of allowed websites.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web content filtering controls are applied to outbound web traffic where appropriate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
For TLS traffic communicated through internet gateways, either of the following approaches are implemented:
• a solution that decrypts and inspects all TLS traffic as per content filtering security controls
• a list of websites to which encrypted connections are allowed, with all other TLS traffic decrypted and inspected as per content filtering security controls.

controls.title: Inspection of Transport Layer Security traffic

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legal advice is sought regarding the inspection of TLS traffic by internet gateways.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A list of allowed websites, using either domain name or IP address, is implemented for all Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) and HTTPS traffic communicated through internet gateways.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If a list of allowed websites is not implemented, a list of allowed website categories is implemented instead.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If a list of allowed websites is not implemented, a list of blocked websites is implemented instead.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If a list of blocked websites is implemented, the list is updated on a daily basis to ensure that it remains effective.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Attempts to access a website through its IP address instead of through its domain name are blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Dynamic domains and other domains where domain names can be registered anonymously for free are blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A web usage policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All web access, including that by internal servers, is conducted through a web proxy.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A web proxy authenticates users and provides logging that includes the following details about websites accessed:
• address (uniform resource locator)
• time/date
• user
• amount of data uploaded and downloaded
• internal and external IP addresses.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated peripheral switch is used when sharing peripherals between official and classified systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A high assurance peripheral switch is used when sharing peripherals between official or classified systems and highly classified systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated, preferably high assurance, peripheral switch is used when sharing peripherals between systems of different classifications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated peripheral switch is used when sharing peripherals between official systems, or classified systems at the same classification, that belong to different security domains.

controls.title: Peripheral switches for particularly important systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An evaluated peripheral switch is used when accessing a system containing AUSTEO or AGAO information and a system of the same classification that is not authorised to process the same caveat.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If procuring an evaluated product, a product that has completed a PP-based evaluation is selected in preference to one that has completed an EAL-based evaluation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Evaluated products are delivered in a manner consistent with any delivery procedures defined in associated evaluation documentation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When procuring high assurance ICT equipment, the ACSC is contacted for any equipment-specific delivery procedures.

controls.title: Installation and configuration of evaluated products

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Evaluated products are installed, configured, administered and operated in accordance with vendor guidance and evaluation documentation.

controls.title: Installation and configuration of evaluated products

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: High assurance ICT equipment is installed, configured, administered and operated in accordance with guidance produced by the ACSC.

controls.title: Use of high assurance ICT equipment in unevaluated configurations

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: High assurance ICT equipment is only operated in an evaluated configuration.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A cloud service provider is used for hosting online services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organisations are notified by cloud service providers of any change to configured regions or availability zones.

controls.title: Availability planning and monitoring for online services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cloud service providers’ ability to dynamically scale resources due to a genuine spike in demand or a denial-of-service attack is tested as part of capacity planning processes.

controls.title: Availability planning and monitoring for online services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where a high availability requirement exists, online services are architected to automatically transition between availability zones.

controls.title: Availability planning and monitoring for online services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where a requirement for high availability exists, a denial of service mitigation service is used.

controls.title: Availability planning and monitoring for online services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organisations perform continuous real-time monitoring of the availability of online services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where a high availability requirement exists for website hosting, CDNs that cache websites are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using a CDN, disclosing the IP address of the web server under the organisation’s control (referred to as the origin server) is avoided and access to the origin server is restricted to the CDN and an authorised management network.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Denial-of-service attack prevention and mitigation strategies are discussed with cloud service providers, specifically:
• their capacity to withstand denial-of-service attacks
• any costs likely to be incurred as a result of denial-of-service attacks
• thresholds for notification of denial-of-service attacks
• thresholds for turning off online services during denial-of-service attacks
• pre-approved actions that can be undertaken during denial-of-service attacks
• denial-of-service attack prevention arrangements with upstream service providers to block malicious traffic as far upstream as possible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The functionality and quality of online services, how to maintain such functionality, and what functionality can be lived without during a denial-of-service attack, are determined and documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Domain names for online services are protected via registrar locking and confirming domain registration details are correct.

controls.title: Monitoring with real-time alerting for online services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Availability monitoring with real-time alerting is implemented to detect denial-of-service attacks and measure their impact.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Critical online services are segregated from other online services that are more likely to be targeted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A static version of a website is pre-prepared that requires minimal processing and bandwidth in order to facilitate at least a basic level of service when under a denial-of-service attack.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All wireless access points are Wi-Fi Alliance certified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Wireless networks provided for the general public to access are segregated from all other networks.

controls.title: Administrative interfaces for wireless access points

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The administrative interface on wireless access points is disabled for wireless network connections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The default SSID of wireless access points is changed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The SSID of a non-public wireless network is not readily associated with an organisation, the location of their premises or the functionality of the wireless network.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SSID broadcasting is enabled on wireless networks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Static addressing is not used for assigning IP addresses on wireless networks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: MAC address filtering is not used to restrict which devices can connect to wireless networks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: WPA2-Enterprise with EAP-TLS is used to perform mutual authentication for wireless networks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Evaluated supplicants, authenticators and authentication servers are used in wireless networks.

controls.title: Generating and issuing certificates for authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Certificates are generated using an evaluated certificate authority solution or hardware security module.

controls.title: Generating and issuing certificates for authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Both device and user certificates are required for accessing wireless networks.

controls.title: Generating and issuing certificates for authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Both device and user certificates for accessing wireless networks are not stored on the same device.

controls.title: Generating and issuing certificates for authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: User certificates for accessing wireless networks are issued on smart cards with access PINs.

controls.title: Generating and issuing certificates for authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: User or device certificates stored on devices accessing wireless networks are protected by encryption.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The PMK caching period is not set to greater than 1440 minutes (24 hours).

controls.title: Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Communications between wireless access points and a RADIUS server are encapsulated with an additional layer of encryption.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ASD approved cryptography is used to protect the confidentiality and integrity of all wireless network traffic.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Wireless networks implement sufficient frequency separation from other wireless networks.

controls.title: Protecting management frames on wireless networks

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Wireless access points enable the use of the 802.11w amendment to protect management frames.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Instead of deploying a small number of wireless access points that broadcast on high power, a greater number of wireless access points that use less broadcast power are deployed to achieve the desired footprint.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The effective range of wireless communications outside an organisation’s area of control is limited by implementing RF shielding on buildings in which wireless networks are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Network documentation includes a high-level network diagram showing all connections into the network; a logical network diagram showing all network devices, critical servers and services; and the configuration of all network devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Network documentation is updated as network configuration changes are made and includes a ‘current as at [date]’ or equivalent statement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Network documentation provided to a third party, or published in public tender documentation, only contains details necessary for other parties to undertake contractual services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Networks are divided into multiple functional network zones according to the sensitivity or criticality of information or services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organisation networks are segregated from service provider networks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: VLANs are not used to separate network traffic between official or classified networks and public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: VLANs are not used to separate network traffic between official and classified networks, or networks of different classifications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: VLANs belonging to different security domains are terminated on separate physical network interfaces.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: VLANs belonging to official and classified networks, or networks of different classifications, do not share VLAN trunks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Network devices implementing VLANs are managed from the most trusted network.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: IPv6 functionality is disabled in dual-stack network devices and ICT equipment unless it is being used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: IPv6 capable network security devices are used on IPv6 and dual-stack networks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unless explicitly required, IPv6 tunnelling is disabled on all network devices and ICT equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: IPv6 tunnelling is blocked by network security devices at externally-connected network boundaries.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Dynamically assigned IPv6 addresses are configured with Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol version 6 in a stateful manner with lease information stored in a centralised logging facility.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Network access controls are implemented on networks to prevent the connection of unauthorised network devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Network access controls are implemented to limit traffic within and between network segments to only those that are required for business purposes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A network device register is maintained and regularly audited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Default accounts for network devices are disabled, renamed or have their passphrase changed.

controls.title: Disabling unused physical ports on network devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unused physical ports on network devices are disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Servers maintain effective functional separation with other servers allowing them to operate independently.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Servers minimise communications with other servers at both the network and file system level.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security measures are implemented to prevent unauthorised access to network management traffic.

controls.title: Use of Simple Network Management Protocol

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SNMP version 1 and 2 are not used on networks.

controls.title: Use of Simple Network Management Protocol

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All default SNMP community strings on network devices are changed and have write access disabled.

controls.title: Using Network-based Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: NIDS or NIPS are deployed in all gateways between an organisation’s networks and other networks they do not manage.

controls.title: Using Network-based Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: NIDS or NIPS in gateways are located immediately inside the outermost firewall and configured to generate a log entry, and an alert, for any information flows that contravene any rule in firewall rule sets.

controls.title: Using Network-based Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When deploying NIDS or NIPS in non-internet gateways, they are configured to monitor unusual patterns of behaviour or traffic flows rather than internet-based communication protocol signatures.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Inbound network connections from anonymity networks to internet-facing services are blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Outbound network connections to anonymity networks are blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Robust web application frameworks are used to aid in the development of secure web applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All web application content is offered exclusively using HTTPS.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Validation and/or sanitisation is performed on all input handled by a web application.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Output encoding is performed on all output produced by a web application.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web applications implement Content-Security-Policy, HSTS and X-Frame-Options response headers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The OWASP Application Security Verification Standard is followed when developing web applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Development, testing and production environments are segregated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Development and modification of software only takes place in development environments.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information in production environments is not used in testing or development environments unless the testing or development environments are secured to the same level as the production environments.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unauthorised access to the authoritative source for software is prevented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Threat modelling and other secure design techniques are used to ensure that threats to software and mitigations to those threats are identified and accounted for.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Platform-specific secure programming practices are used when developing software, including using the lowest privilege needed to achieve a task, checking return values of all system calls, validating all inputs and encrypting all communications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Software is tested for security vulnerabilities by software developers, as well as an independent party, before it is used in a production environment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A vulnerability disclosure program is implemented to assist with the secure development and maintenance of products and services.

groups.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony

controls.title: Video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony infrastructure hardening

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Video conferencing and IP telephony infrastructure is hardened.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where a requirement exists to implement a firewall in a gateway, and video conferencing or IP telephony traffic passes through the gateway, a video or voice-aware firewall is used.

controls.title: Protecting video conferencing and Internet Protocol telephony traffic

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Video conferencing and IP telephony signalling and data is encrypted.

controls.title: Establishment of secure signalling and data protocols

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Video conferencing and IP telephony functions are established using secure signalling and data protocols.

controls.title: Video conferencing unit and Internet Protocol phone authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An encrypted and non-replayable two-way authentication scheme is used for call authentication and authorisation.

controls.title: Video conferencing unit and Internet Protocol phone authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Authentication and authorisation is used for all actions on a video conferencing network, including call setup and changing settings.

controls.title: Video conferencing unit and Internet Protocol phone authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Authentication and authorisation is used for all actions on an IP telephony network, including registering a new IP phone, changing phone users, changing settings and accessing voicemail.

controls.title: Video conferencing unit and Internet Protocol phone authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
IP telephony is configured such that:
• IP phones authenticate themselves to the call controller upon registration
• auto-registration is disabled and only authorised devices are allowed to access the network
• unauthorised devices are blocked by default
• all unused and prohibited functionality is disabled.

controls.title: Video conferencing unit and Internet Protocol phone authentication

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Individual logins are used for IP phones.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Video conferencing and IP telephony traffic is separated physically or logically from other data traffic.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Workstations are not connected to video conferencing units or IP phones unless the workstation or the device uses VLANs or similar mechanisms to maintain separation between video conferencing, IP telephony and other data traffic.

controls.title: Internet Protocol phones in public areas

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Traditional analog phones are used in public areas.

controls.title: Internet Protocol phones in public areas

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If IP phones are used in public areas, their ability to access data networks, voicemail and directory services are prevented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microphones (including headsets and USB handsets) and webcams are not used with non-SECRET workstations in SECRET areas.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microphones (including headsets and USB handsets) and webcams are not used with non-TOP SECRET workstations in TOP SECRET areas.

controls.title: Developing a denial of service response plan

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A denial of service response plan is developed and implemented that includes:
• how to identify signs of a denial of service
• how to identify the source of a denial of service
• how capabilities can be maintained during a denial of service
• what actions can be taken to clear a denial of service.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A telephone systems usage policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised of the permitted sensitivity or classification of information that can be discussed over both internal and external telephone systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised of security risks posed by non-secure telephone systems in areas where sensitive or classified conversations can occur.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When permitting different levels of conversation for different kinds of connections, telephone systems give a visual indication of what kind of connection has been made.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Telephone systems used for sensitive or classified conversations encrypt all traffic that passes over external systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cordless telephone systems are not used for sensitive or classified conversations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Speakerphones are not used on telephone systems in TOP SECRET areas unless the telephone system is located in a room rated as audio secure, the room is audio secure during conversations and only personnel involved in discussions are present in the room.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In PROTECTED areas, off-hook audio protection features are used on all telephones that are not authorised for the transmission of PROTECTED information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In SECRET areas, push-to-talk handsets are used on all telephones that are not authorised for the transmission of SECRET information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In TOP SECRET areas, push-to-talk handsets are used on all telephones that are not authorised for the transmission of TOP SECRET information.

controls.title: Fax machine and multifunction device usage policy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A fax machine and MFD usage policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Separate fax machines or MFDs are used for sending sensitive or classified fax messages and all other fax messages.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When sending fax messages, the fax message is encrypted to an appropriate level to be communicated over unsecured telecommunications infrastructure or the PSTN.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The sender of a fax message makes arrangements for the receiver to collect the fax message as soon as possible after it is received and notify the sender if the fax message does not arrive in an agreed amount of time.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security controls for MFDs connected to a network are of a similar strength to those for other devices on the network.

controls.title: Connecting multifunction devices to both networks and digital telephone systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A direct connection from an MFD to a digital telephone system is not enabled unless the digital telephone system is authorised to operate at the same sensitivity or classification as the network to which the MFD is connected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: MFDs connected to networks are not used to copy documents above the sensitivity or classification of the connected network.

controls.title: Observing fax machine and multifunction device use

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Fax machines and MFDs are located in areas where their use can be observed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Hard disks of database servers are encrypted using full disk encryption.

controls.title: Functional separation between database servers and web servers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Database servers and web servers are functionally separated, physically or virtually.

controls.title: Communications between database servers and web servers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information communicated between database servers and web applications is encrypted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Database servers that require network connectivity are placed on a different network segment to an organisation’s workstations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Network access controls are implemented to restrict database server communications to strictly defined network resources such as web servers, application servers and storage area networks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If only local access to a database is required, networking functionality of database management system (DBMS) software is disabled or directed to listen solely to the localhost interface.

controls.title: Separation of production, test and development database servers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Test and development environments do not use the same database servers as production environments.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All temporary installation files and logs are removed after DBMS software has been installed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DBMS software is configured according to vendor guidance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DBMS software features, stored procedures, accounts and databases that are not required are disabled or removed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DBMS software is configured to run as a separate account with the minimum privileges needed to perform its functions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The account under which DBMS software runs has limited access to non-essential areas of the database server’s file system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The ability of DBMS software to read local files from a server is disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Default database administrator accounts are disabled, renamed or have their passphrases changed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Database administrators have unique and identifiable accounts.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Database administrator accounts are not shared across different databases.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Database administrator accounts are used exclusively for administrative tasks, with standard database accounts used for general purpose interactions with databases.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Database administrator access is restricted to defined roles rather than accounts with default administrative permissions, or all permissions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A database register is maintained and regularly audited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: File-based access controls are applied to database files.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Passphrases stored in databases are hashed with a uniquely salted Australian Signals Directorate Approved Cryptographic Algorithm.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Databases and their contents are classified based on the sensitivity or classification of information that they contain.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Database users’ ability to access, insert, modify and remove content in databases is restricted based on their work duties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The need-to-know principle is enforced for database contents through the application of minimum privileges, database views and database roles.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where concerns exist that the sum, or aggregation, of separate pieces of information from within databases could lead to a database user determining more sensitive or classified information, database views in combination with database user access roles are implemented.

controls.title: Separation of production, test and development databases

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information in production databases is not used in testing or development databases unless the testing or development environments are secured to the same level as the production environment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All queries to databases from web applications are filtered for legitimate content and correct syntax.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Parameterised queries or stored procedures are used for database interaction instead of dynamically generated queries.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web applications are designed to provide as little error information as possible to users about database schemas.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An email usage policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to non-approved webmail services is blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Protective markings are applied to emails and reflect the information in their subject, body and attachments.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Protective marking tools do not automatically insert protective markings into emails.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Protective marking tools do not allow users to select protective markings that a system has not been authorised to process, store or communicate.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Protective marking tools do not allow users replying to or forwarding an email to select a protective marking that is lower than previously used for the email.

controls.title: Handling emails with inappropriate, invalid or missing protective markings

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Email servers are configured to block, log and report emails with inappropriate protective markings.

controls.title: Handling emails with inappropriate, invalid or missing protective markings

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The intended recipients of any blocked inbound emails, and the sender of any blocked outbound emails, are notified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Emails containing AUSTEO, AGAO or REL information are only sent to named recipients and not to groups or distribution lists unless the nationality of all members of the distribution lists can be confirmed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Email is routed through a centralised email gateway.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When users send email from outside their network, an authenticated and encrypted channel is configured to allow email to be routed via a centralised email gateway.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where backup or alternative email gateways are in place, they are maintained at the same standard as the primary email gateway.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Email servers only relay emails destined for or originating from their domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Opportunistic TLS encryption, as defined in IETF RFC 3207, is enabled on email servers that make incoming or outgoing email connections over public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: MTA-STS, as defined in IETF RFC 8461, is enabled to prevent the transfer of unencrypted emails between complying servers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SPF is used to specify authorised email services (or lack thereof) for all domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A hard fail SPF record is used when specifying email servers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SPF is used to verify the authenticity of incoming emails.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Incoming emails that fail SPF checks are blocked or marked in a manner that is visible to the recipients.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DKIM signing is enabled on emails originating from an organisation’s domains.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DKIM signatures on received emails are verified.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Email distribution list software used by external senders is configured such that it does not break the validity of the sender’s DKIM signature.

controls.title: Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DMARC records are configured for all domains such that emails are rejected if they fail SPF or DKIM checks.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Email content filtering controls are implemented for email bodies and attachments.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Emails arriving via an external connection where the source address uses an internal domain name are blocked at the email gateway.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Notification of undeliverable, bounced or blocked emails are only sent to senders that can be verified via SPF or other trusted means.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only the latest version of TLS is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: AES in Galois Counter Mode is used for symmetric encryption.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only server-initiated secure renegotiation is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DH or ECDH is used for key establishment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using DH or ECDH for key establishment, the ephemeral variant is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Anonymous DH is not used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SHA-2-based certificates are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cipher suites are configured to use SHA-2 as part of the Message Authentication Code and Pseudo-Random Function.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: TLS compression is disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PFS is used for TLS connections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only AACAs are used by cryptographic equipment and software.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ECDH and ECDSA are used in preference to DH and DSA.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using DH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a modulus of at least 1024 bits, preferably 2048 bits, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using DSA for digital signatures, a modulus of at least 1024 bits, preferably 2048 bits, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using elliptic curve cryptography, a curve from FIPS 186-4 is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using ECDH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a field/key size of at least 160 bits, preferably 256 bits, is used.

controls.title: Using the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using ECDSA for digital signatures, a field/key size of at least 160 bits, preferably 256 bits, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using RSA for digital signatures, and passing encryption session keys or similar keys, a modulus of at least 1024 bits, preferably 2048 bits, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using RSA for digital signatures, and for passing encryption session keys or similar keys, a key pair for passing encrypted session keys that is different from the key pair used for digital signatures is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A hashing algorithm from the SHA-2 family is used instead of SHA-1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Symmetric cryptographic algorithms are not used in Electronic Codebook Mode.

controls.title: Using the Triple Data Encryption Standard

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: 3DES is used with three distinct keys.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: AACAs are used in an evaluated implementation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Preference is given to using the CNSA Suite algorithms and key sizes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Keyed CGCE is transported based on the sensitivity or classification of the keying material in it.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The compromise or suspected compromise of CGCE or associated keying material is reported to an organisation’s Chief Information Security Officer, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after it occurs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Keying material is changed when compromised or suspected of being compromised.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ACSI 53 E, ACSI 103 A, ACSI 105 B, ACSI 107 B, ACSI 173 A and the latest equipment-specific doctrine is complied with when using HACE.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic equipment is stored in a room that meets the requirements for a server room based on the sensitivity or classification of the information the cryptographic equipment processes.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Areas in which HACE is used are separated from other areas and designated as a cryptographic controlled area.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of SSH version 1 is disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The configuration settings in the following table are implemented for the SSH daemon (see source document for referenced table).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Public key-based authentication is used for SSH connections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SSH private keys are protected with a passphrase or a key encryption key.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
When using logins without a passphrase for automated purposes, the following are disabled:
• access from IP addresses that do not require access
• port forwarding
• agent credential forwarding
• X11 display remoting
• console access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using remote access without the use of a passphrase, the ‘forced command’ option is used to specify what command is executed and parameter checked is enabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When SSH-agent or other similar key caching programs are used, it is only on workstations and servers with screen locks, key caches are set to expire within four hours of inactivity, and agent credential forwarding is enabled only when SSH traversal is required.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only AACPs are used by cryptographic equipment and software.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Versions of S/MIME earlier than 3.0 are not used.

controls.title: Reducing physical storage and handling requirements

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Encryption software that implements an ASD Approved Cryptographic Algorithm (AACA) is used if an organisation wishes to reduce the physical storage or handling requirements for ICT equipment or media that contains sensitive information.

controls.title: Reducing physical storage and handling requirements

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Encryption software that has completed an ACE is used if an organisation wishes to reduce the physical storage or handling requirements for ICT equipment or media that contains classified information.

controls.title: Reducing physical storage and handling requirements

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: HACE is used if an organisation wishes to reduce the physical storage or handling requirements for ICT equipment or media that contains highly classified information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Encryption software used for data at rest implements full disk encryption, or partial encryption where access controls will only allow writing to the encrypted partition.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: HACE used for data at rest implements full disk encryption, or partial encryption where access controls will only allow writing to the encrypted partition.

controls.title: Encrypting particularly important information at rest

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition to any encryption already in place, an AACA is used to encrypt AUSTEO and AGAO information when at rest on a system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where practical, cryptographic equipment and encryption software provides a means of data recovery to allow for circumstances where the encryption key is unavailable due to loss, damage or failure.

controls.title: Handling encrypted ICT equipment and media

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a user authenticates to encryption functionality for ICT equipment or media storing encrypted information, it is treated in accordance with its original sensitivity or classification until such a time that the user deauthenticates from the encryption functionality.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic equipment or encryption software that implements an ASD Approved Cryptographic Protocol (AACP) is used to communicate sensitive information over public network infrastructure and through unsecured spaces.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic equipment or encryption software that has completed an ACE is used to communicate classified information over official networks, public network infrastructure and through unsecured spaces.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: HACE is used to communicate highly classified information over networks of a lower classification, official networks, public network infrastructure and through unsecured spaces.

controls.title: Encrypting particularly important information in transit

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In addition to any encryption already in place, an AACP is used to protect AUSTEO and AGAO information when communicated across network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Tunnel mode is used for IPsec connections; however, if using transport mode, an IP tunnel is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The ESP protocol is used for IPsec connections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: IKE is used for key exchange when establishing an IPsec connection.

controls.title: Internet Security Association Key Management Protocol modes

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using ISAKMP in IKE version 1, aggressive mode is disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A security association lifetime of less than four hours, or 14400 seconds, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: HMAC-SHA256, HMAC-SHA384 or HMAC-SHA512 is used as a HMAC algorithm.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The largest modulus size possible for all relevant components in the network is used when conducting a key exchange.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PFS is used for IPsec connections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of XAuth is disabled for IPsec connections using IKE version 1.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Systems have a system security plan that includes a description of the system and an annex that covers both security controls from this document (based on the system’s classification, functionality and technologies) and any additional security controls that have been identified for the system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Systems have an incident response plan that covers the following:
• guidelines on what constitutes a cyber security incident
• the types of incidents likely to be encountered and the expected response to each type
• how to report cyber security incidents, internally to the organisation and externally to the Australian Cyber Security Centre (ACSC)
• other parties which need to be informed in the event of a cyber security incident
• the authority, or authorities, responsible for investigating and responding to cyber security incidents
• the criteria by which an investigation of a cyber security incident would be requested from a law enforcement agency, the ACSC or other relevant authority
• the steps necessary to ensure the integrity of evidence relating to a cyber security incident
• system contingency measures or a reference to such details if they are located in a separate document.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Systems have a continuous monitoring plan that includes:
• conducting vulnerability scans for systems at least monthly
• conducting vulnerability assessments or penetration tests for systems at least annually
• analysing identified security vulnerabilities to determine their potential impact and appropriate mitigations based on effectiveness, cost and existing security controls
• using a risk-based approach to prioritise the implementation of identified mitigations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
At the conclusion of a security assessment for a system, a security assessment report is produced by the assessor and covers:
• the scope of the security assessment
• the system’s strengths and weaknesses
• security risks associated with the operation of the system
• the effectiveness of the implementation of security controls
• any recommended remediation actions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At the conclusion of a security assessment for a system, a plan of action and milestones is produced by the system owner.

groups.title: Development and maintenance of security documentation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A cyber security strategy is developed and implemented for the organisation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organisational-level security documentation is approved by the Chief Information Security Officer while system-specific security documentation is approved by the system’s authorising officer.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security documentation is reviewed at least annually and includes a ‘current as at [date]’ or equivalent statement.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security documentation, including notification of subsequent changes, is communicated to all stakeholders.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Cyber security awareness training is undertaken annually by all personnel and covers:
• the purpose of the cyber security awareness training
• security appointments and contacts within the organisation
• authorised use of systems and their resources
• protection of systems and their resources
• reporting of cyber security incidents and suspected compromises of systems and their resources.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Tailored privileged user training is undertaken annually by all privileged users.

controls.title: Reporting suspicious contact via online services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised of what suspicious contact via online services is and how to report it.

controls.title: Posting work information to online services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised to not post work information to unauthorised online services and to report cases where such information is posted.

controls.title: Posting work information to online services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised to maintain separate work and personal accounts for online services.

controls.title: Posting personal information to online services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised of security risks associated with posting personal information to online services and are encouraged to use any available privacy settings to restrict who can view such information.

controls.title: Sending and receiving files via online services

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised not to send or receive files via unauthorised online services.

groups.title: Access to systems and their resources

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each system’s system security plan specifies any requirements for access to the system and its resources.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel undergo appropriate employment screening, and where necessary hold an appropriate security clearance, before being granted access to a system and its resources.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel receive any necessary briefings before being granted access to a system and its resources.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel granted access to a system and its resources are uniquely identifiable.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of shared user accounts is strictly controlled, and personnel using such accounts are uniquely identifiable.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel who are contractors are identified as such.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel who are foreign nationals are identified as such, including by their specific nationality.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where systems process, store or communicate AUSTEO, AGAO or REL information, personnel who are foreign nationals are identified as such, including by their specific nationality.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Standard access to systems, applications and data repositories is validated when first requested and revalidated on an annual or more frequent basis.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Standard access to systems, applications and data repositories is limited to that required for personnel to undertake their duties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of standard accounts, and any activities undertaken with them, are monitored and audited.

controls.title: Standard access to systems by foreign nationals

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Foreign nationals, including seconded foreign nationals, do not have access to systems that process, store or communicate AUSTEO or REL information unless effective security controls are in place to ensure such information is not accessible to them.

controls.title: Standard access to systems by foreign nationals

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Foreign nationals, excluding seconded foreign nationals, do not have access to systems that process, store or communicate AGAO information unless effective security controls are in place to ensure such information is not accessible to them.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Privileged access to systems, applications and data repositories is validated when first requested and revalidated on an annual or more frequent basis.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Privileged access to systems, applications and data repositories is limited to that required for personnel to undertake their duties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Privileged users are assigned a dedicated privileged account to be used solely for tasks requiring privileged access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of privileged accounts, and any activities undertaken with them, are monitored and audited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Technical security controls are used to prevent privileged users from reading emails, browsing the web and obtaining files via online services.

controls.title: Privileged access to systems by foreign nationals

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Foreign nationals, excluding seconded foreign nationals, do not have privileged access to systems, applications and data repositories.

controls.title: Privileged access to systems by foreign nationals

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Foreign nationals, including seconded foreign nationals, do not have privileged access to systems that process, store or communicate AUSTEO or REL information.

controls.title: Privileged access to systems by foreign nationals

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Foreign nationals, excluding seconded foreign nationals, do not have privileged access to systems that process, store or communicate AGAO information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to systems, applications and data repositories is removed or suspended on the same day personnel no longer have a legitimate requirement for access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to systems, applications and data repositories is removed or suspended as soon as practicable when personnel are detected undertaking malicious activities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to systems, applications and data repositories is removed or suspended after one month of inactivity.

controls.title: Recording authorisation for personnel to access systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A secure record is maintained for the life of each system covering:
• all personnel authorised to access the system, and their user identification
• who provided authorisation for access
• when access was granted
• the level of access that was granted
• when access, and the level of access, was last reviewed
• when the level of access was changed, and to what extent (if applicable)
• when access was withdrawn (if applicable).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When personnel are granted temporary access to a system, effective security controls are put in place to restrict their access to only information required for them to undertake their duties.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Temporary access is not granted to systems that process, store or communicate caveated or sensitive compartmented information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A method of emergency access to systems is documented and tested at least once when initially implemented and each time fundamental information technology infrastructure changes occur.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Break glass accounts are only used when normal authentication processes cannot be used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Break glass accounts are only used for specific authorised activities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Break glass accounts are monitored and audited for unauthorised use or modification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Break glass account credentials are changed by the account custodian after they are accessed by any other party.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Break glass accounts are tested after credentials are changed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Systems processing, storing or communicating AUSTEO or AGAO information remain at all times under the control of an Australian national working for or on behalf of the Australian Government.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to AUSTEO or AGAO information from systems not under the sole control of the Australian Government is prevented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users are authenticated before they are granted access to a system and its resources.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate standard users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate all privileged users and any other positions of trust.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate privileged users each time they perform privileged actions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate all users of remote access solutions.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate all users when accessing important data repositories.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Multi-factor authentication uses at least two of the following authentication factors: passwords, Universal 2nd Factor security keys, physical one-time password tokens, biometrics or smartcards.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Passwords used for multi-factor authentication are a minimum of 6 characters.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Passwords used for multi-factor authentication are a minimum of 8 characters.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Passwords used for multi-factor authentication are a minimum of 10 characters.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When multi-factor authentication is implemented, none of the authentication factors on their own can be used for single-factor authentication to another system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When systems cannot support multi-factor authentication, single-factor authentication using passphrases is implemented instead.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication are a minimum of 14 characters with complexity, ideally as 4 random words.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication are a minimum of 17 characters with complexity, ideally as 5 random words.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication are a minimum of 20 characters with complexity, ideally as 6 random words.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Passphrases used for single-factor authentication:
• are not constructed from song lyrics, movies, literature or any other publicly available material
• do not form a real sentence in a natural language
• are not a list of categorised words.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Passphrases used for single-factor authentication can not be used to authenticate to multiple different systems.

controls.title: Setting and resetting credentials for user accounts

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Passwords/passphrases set or reset on users’ behalf are randomly generated.

controls.title: Setting and resetting credentials for user accounts

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users provide sufficient evidence to verify their identity when collecting a password/passphrase for their account.

controls.title: Setting and resetting credentials for user accounts

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Passwords/passphrases are provided to users via a secure communications channel or, if not possible, split into parts with part being provided to the user and part provided to the user’s supervisor.

controls.title: Setting and resetting credentials for user accounts

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users that do not set their own initial password/passphrase are required to change it on first use.

controls.title: Setting and resetting credentials for service accounts

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Service accounts are created as group Managed Service Accounts.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Accounts are locked out after a maximum of five failed logon attempts.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Repeated account lockouts are investigated before reauthorising access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users provide sufficient evidence to verify their identity when requesting an account unlock.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Authentication methods susceptible to replay attacks are disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: LAN Manager and NT LAN Manager authentication methods are disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Privileged accounts are members of the Protected Users security group.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Credentials are stored separately from systems to which they grant access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Credentials are obscured as they are entered into systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Stored passwords/passphrases are protected by ensuring they are hashed, salted and stretched.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Passwords/passphrases are changed if:
• they are directly compromised
• they are suspected of being compromised
• they appear in online data breach databases
• they are discovered stored in the clear on a network
• they are discovered being transferred in the clear across a network
• membership of a shared account changes
• they have not been changed in the past 12 months.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Outside of business hours, and after an appropriate period of inactivity, user sessions are terminated and workstations are rebooted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Systems are configured with a session or screen lock that:
• activates after a maximum of 15 minutes of user inactivity or if manually activated by the user
• completely conceals all information on the screen
• ensures that the screen does not enter a power saving state before the screen or session lock is activated
• requires the user to reauthenticate to unlock the system
• denies users the ability to disable the session or screen locking mechanism.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Systems have a logon banner that requires users to acknowledge and accept their security responsibilities before access is granted.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legal advice is sought on the exact wording of logon banners.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SOEs are used for workstations and servers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SOEs provided by third parties are scanned for malicious content and configurations before being used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SOEs are reviewed and updated at least annually.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The latest version (N), or N-1 version, of an operating system is used for SOEs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When developing a Microsoft Windows SOE, the 64-bit version of the operating system is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ACSC and vendor guidance is implemented to assist in hardening the configuration of operating systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Default operating system accounts are disabled, renamed or have their passphrase changed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unneeded operating system accounts, software, components, services and functionality are removed or disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Standard users are prevented from bypassing, disabling or modifying security functionality of operating systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Standard users are prevented from running script execution engines in Microsoft Windows, including:
• Windows Script Host (cscript.exe and wscript.exe)
• PowerShell (powershell.exe, powershell_ise.exe and pwsh.exe)
• Command Prompt (cmd.exe)
• Windows Management Instrumentation (wmic.exe) 
• Microsoft HTML Application Host (mshta.exe).

parts.name: statement
