parts.prose: Local administrator accounts are disabled; alternatively, passphrases that are random and unique for each device’s local administrator account are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unique domain accounts with local administrative privileges, but without domain administrative privileges, are used for workstation and server management.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users do not have the ability to install unapproved software.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users do not have the ability to uninstall or disable approved software.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Application control is implemented on all workstations to restrict the execution of executables, software libraries, scripts and installers to an approved set.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Application control is implemented on all servers to restrict the execution of executables, software libraries, scripts and installers to an approved set.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Application control is implemented using cryptographic hash rules, publisher certificate rules or path rules.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cryptographic hash rules, publisher certificate rules and path rules used for application control are validated at least annually.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When implementing application control using publisher certificate rules, both publisher names and product names are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When implementing application control using path rules, file system permissions are configured to prevent unauthorised modification of folder and file permissions, folder contents (including adding new files) and individual files that are approved to execute.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft’s latest recommended block rules are implemented to prevent application control bypasses.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All users (with the exception of privileged users when performing specific administrative activities) cannot disable, bypass or be exempted from application control.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Application control is configured to generate event logs for failed execution attempts, including information such as the name of the blocked file, the date/time stamp and the username of the user attempting to execute the file.

controls.title: Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit and exploit protection

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If supported, the latest version of Microsoft’s EMET is implemented on workstations and servers and configured with both operating system mitigation measures and application-specific mitigation measures.

controls.title: Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit and exploit protection

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If supported, Microsoft's exploit protection functionality is implemented on workstations and servers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PowerShell 2.0 and below is removed from operating systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PowerShell is configured to use Constrained Language Mode.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PowerShell is configured to use module logging, script block logging and transcription functionality.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: PowerShell script block logs are protected by Protected Event Logging functionality.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A HIPS is implemented on workstations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A HIPS is implemented on high value servers such as authentication servers, Domain Name System (DNS) servers, web servers, file servers and email servers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A software firewall is implemented on workstations and servers to limit both inbound and outbound network connections.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Antivirus software is implemented on workstations and servers and configured with:
• signature-based detection enabled and set to a high level
• heuristic-based detection enabled and set to a high level
• detection signatures checked for currency and updated on at least a daily basis
• automatic and regular scanning configured for all fixed disks and removable media.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Antivirus software has reputation rating functionality enabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Device access control software is implemented on workstations and servers to prevent unauthorised devices from being connected.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: External interfaces of workstations and servers that allow DMA are disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Applications are chosen from vendors that have made a commitment to secure development and maintenance practices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The latest releases of key business applications such as office productivity suites, PDF viewers, web browsers, common web browser plugins, email clients and software platforms are used when present within SOEs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The latest releases of web server software, server applications that store important data, and other internet-accessible server applications are used when present within SOEs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ACSC and vendor guidance is implemented to assist in hardening the configuration of Microsoft Office, web browsers and PDF viewers.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web browsers are configured to block or disable support for Flash content.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web browsers are configured to block web advertisements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web browsers are configured to block Java from the internet.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft Office is configured to disable support for Flash content.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft Office is configured to prevent activation of Object Linking and Embedding packages.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any unrequired functionality in Microsoft Office, web browsers and PDF viewers is disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The use of Microsoft Office, web browser and PDF viewer add-ons is restricted to organisation approved add-ons.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If supported, Microsoft’s Attack Surface Reduction rules are implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Standard users are prevented from bypassing, disabling or modifying security functionality of applications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft Office macros are only allowed to execute in documents from Trusted Locations where write access is limited to personnel whose role is to vet and approve macros.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft Office macros in documents originating from the internet are blocked.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Microsoft Office macro security settings cannot be changed by users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the isolation mechanism is from a vendor that uses secure coding practices and, when security vulnerabilities have been identified, develops and distributes patches in a timely manner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the configuration of the isolation mechanism is hardened by removing unneeded functionality and restricting access to the administrative interface used to manage the isolation mechanism.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the underlying operating system running on the server is hardened.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, patches are applied to the isolation mechanism and underlying operating system in a timely manner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, integrity and log monitoring are performed for the isolation mechanism and underlying operating system in a timely manner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the physical server and all computing environments running on the physical server are of the same classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the physical server and all computing environments running on the physical server are controlled by the same organisation, are of the same classification and are within the same security domain.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An event logging policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A centralised logging facility is implemented and systems are configured to save event logs to the centralised logging facility as soon as possible after each event occurs.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An accurate time source is established and used consistently across systems and network devices to assist with the correlation of events.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For any system requiring authentication, logon, failed logon and logoff events are logged.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
The following events are logged for operating systems:
• access to important data and processes
• application crashes and any error messages
• attempts to use special privileges
• changes to accounts
• changes to security policy
• changes to system configurations
• Domain Name System (DNS) and Hypertext Transfer Protocol requests
• failed attempts to access data and system resources
• service failures and restarts
• system startup and shutdown
• transfer of data to and from external media
• user or group management
• use of special privileges.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
The following events are logged for web applications:
• attempted access that is denied
• crashes and any error messages
• search queries initiated by users.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
The following events are logged for databases:
• access to particularly important information
• addition of new users, especially privileged users
• any query containing comments
• any query containing multiple embedded queries
• any query or database alerts or failures
• attempts to elevate privileges
• attempted access that is successful or unsuccessful
• changes to the database structure
• changes to user roles or database permissions
• database administrator actions
• database logons and logoffs
• modifications to data
• use of executable commands.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: For each event logged, the date and time of the event, the relevant user or process, the event description, and the ICT equipment involved are recorded.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Event logs are protected from unauthorised access, modification and deletion.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Event logs are retained for a minimum of 7 years in accordance with the National Archives of Australia’s Administrative Functions Disposal Authority Express Version 2 publication.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: DNS and proxy logs are retained for at least 18 months.

controls.title: Event log auditing process and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An event log auditing process, and supporting event log auditing procedures, is developed and implemented covering the scope and schedule of audits, what constitutes a violation of security policy, and actions to be taken when violations are detected, including reporting requirements.

controls.title: Event log auditing process and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Events are correlated across event logs to prioritise audits and focus investigations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber security incidents are reported to an organisation’s CISO, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after they occur or are discovered.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Service providers report all cyber security incidents to the organisation’s CISO, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after they occur or are discovered.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organisations and service providers maintain 24x7 contact details for each other in order to report cyber security incidents.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organisations and service providers provide each other with additional out-of-band contact details for use when normal communication channels fail.

controls.title: Reporting cyber security incidents to the ACSC

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber security incidents are reported to the ACSC.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A cyber security incident register is maintained with the following information:
• the date the cyber security incident occurred
• the date the cyber security incident was discovered
• a description of the cyber security incident
• any actions taken in response to the cyber security incident
• to whom the cyber security incident was reported.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When a data spill occurs, information owners are advised and access to the information is restricted.

controls.title: Handling and containing malicious code infections

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
When malicious code is detected, the following steps are taken to handle the infection:
• the infected systems are isolated
• all previously connected media used in the period leading up to the infection are scanned for signs of infection and isolated if necessary
• antivirus software is used to remove the infection from infected systems and media
• if the infection cannot be reliably removed, systems are restored from a known good backup or rebuilt.

controls.title: Allowing targeted cyber intrusions to continue

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legal advice is sought before allowing targeted cyber intrusion activity to continue on a system for the purpose of collecting further information or evidence.

controls.title: Allowing targeted cyber intrusions to continue

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System owners are consulted before allowing targeted cyber intrusion activity to continue on a system for the purpose of collecting further information or evidence.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Post-incident analysis is performed for successful targeted cyber intrusions; this includes storing full network traffic for at least seven days after a targeted cyber intrusion.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
The integrity of evidence gathered during an investigation is maintained by investigators:
• recording all of their actions
• creating checksums for all evidence
• copying evidence onto media for archiving
• maintaining a proper chain of custody.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An intrusion detection and prevention policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A trusted insider program is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legal advice is sought regarding the development and implementation of a trusted insider program.

controls.title: Access to sufficient data sources and tools

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber security personnel have access to sufficient data sources and tools to ensure that systems can be monitored for key indicators of compromise.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A mobile device usage policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised of the sensitivity or classification permitted for voice and data communications when using mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Paging, Multimedia Message Service, Short Message Service or instant messaging apps are not used to communicate sensitive or classified information.

controls.title: Using mobile devices in public spaces

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Sensitive or classified information is not viewed or communicated in public locations unless care is taken to reduce the chance of conversations being overheard or the screen of a mobile device being observed.

controls.title: Using mobile devices in public spaces

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Privacy filters are applied to the screens of highly classified mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices are kept under continual direct supervision when being actively used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices are carried or stored in a secured state when not being actively used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If unable to apply encryption to mobile devices that is suitable for them to be carried through areas not authorised to process the information stored on them, they are physically transferred in a security briefcase or an approved multi-use satchel, pouch or transit bag.

controls.title: Mobile device emergency sanitisation process and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A mobile device emergency sanitisation process, and supporting mobile device emergency sanitisation procedures, is developed and implemented.

controls.title: Mobile device emergency sanitisation process and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If a cryptographic zeroise or sanitise function is provided for cryptographic keys on highly classified mobile devices, the function is used as part of the mobile device emergency sanitisation process.

controls.title: Before travelling overseas with mobile devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are advised of privacy and security risks when travelling overseas with mobile devices.

controls.title: Before travelling overseas with mobile devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
If travelling overseas with mobile devices to high/extreme risk countries, personnel are:
• issued with newly provisioned accounts and devices from a pool of dedicated travel devices which are used solely for work-related activities
• advised on how to apply and inspect tamper seals to key areas of devices
• advised to avoid taking any personal devices, especially if rooted or jailbroken.

controls.title: Before travelling overseas with mobile devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Before travelling overseas with mobile devices, personnel take the following actions:
• record all details of the devices being taken, such as product types, serial numbers and International Mobile Equipment Identity numbers
• update all applications and operating systems
• remove all non-essential accounts, applications and data
• apply security configuration settings, such as lock screens
• configure remote locate and wipe functionality
• enable encryption, including for any media used
• backup all important data and configuration settings.

controls.title: While travelling overseas with mobile devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Personnel take the following precautions when travelling overseas with mobile devices:
• never leaving devices or media unattended for any period of time, including by placing them in checked-in luggage or leaving them in hotel safes
• never storing credentials with devices that they grant access to, such as in laptop bags
• never lending devices to untrusted people, even if briefly
• never allowing untrusted people to connect other devices or media to their devices, including for charging
• never using designated charging stations, wall outlet charging ports or chargers supplied by untrusted people
• avoiding connecting devices to open or untrusted Wi-Fi networks
• using an approved Virtual Private Network to encrypt all device communications
• using encrypted mobile applications for communications instead of using foreign telecommunication networks
• disabling any communications capabilities of devices when not in use, such as cellular data, wireless, Bluetooth and Near Field Communication
• avoiding reuse of media once used with other parties’ devices or systems
• ensuring any media used for data transfers are thoroughly checked for malicious code beforehand
• never using any gifted devices, especially media, when travelling or upon returning from travelling.

controls.title: While travelling overseas with mobile devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Personnel report the potential compromise of mobile devices, media or credentials to their organisation as soon as possible, especially if they:
• provide credentials, decrypt devices or have devices taken out of sight by foreign government officials
• have devices or media stolen that are later returned
• lose devices or media that are later found
• observe unusual behaviour of devices.

controls.title: After travelling overseas with mobile devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Upon returning from travelling overseas with mobile devices, personnel take the following actions:
• sanitise and reset devices, including all media used with them
• decommission any physical credentials that left their possession during their travel
• report if significant doubt exists as to the integrity of any devices following their travel.

controls.title: After travelling overseas with mobile devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
If returning from travelling overseas with mobile devices to high/extreme risk countries, personnel take the following additional actions:
• reset user credentials used with devices, including those used for remote access to their organisation’s systems
• monitor accounts for any indicators of compromise, such as failed login attempts.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A mobile device management policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A Mobile Device Management solution is used to ensure mobile device management policy is applied to all mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices do not process, store or communicate TOP SECRET information unless explicitly approved by the ACSC to do so.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel accessing official or classified systems or information using a privately-owned mobile device use an ACSC approved platform, a security configuration in accordance with ACSC guidance, and have enforced separation of official and classified information from any personal information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Privately-owned mobile devices do not access highly classified systems or information.

controls.title: Seeking legal advice for privately-owned mobile devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legal advice is sought prior to allowing privately-owned mobile devices to access official or classified systems or information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel accessing official or classified systems or information using an organisation-owned mobile device use an ACSC approved platform with a security configuration in accordance with ACSC guidance.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All information on mobile devices is encrypted using at least an Australian Signals Directorate Approved Cryptographic Algorithm.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices used to communicate sensitive or classified information over public network infrastructure use encryption approved for communicating such information over public network infrastructure.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The range of Bluetooth communications between mobile devices and other Bluetooth devices is restricted to less than 10 metres by using class 2 or class 3 Bluetooth devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Bluetooth functionality is not enabled on highly classified mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices are configured to remain undiscoverable to other Bluetooth devices except during Bluetooth pairing.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Bluetooth pairing is performed using Bluetooth version 2.1 or later.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Bluetooth pairing is performed in a manner such that connections are only made between intended Bluetooth devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Bluetooth pairings are removed from mobile devices when there is no longer a requirement for their use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices prevent personnel from installing or uninstalling applications once provisioned.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices prevent personnel from disabling or modifying security functions once provisioned.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile carriers that are able to provide timely security updates for mobile devices are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mobile devices are able to accept security updates from mobile carriers as soon as they become available.

controls.title: Connecting mobile devices to the internet

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Web browsing from mobile devices is conducted through an organisation’s internet gateway rather than via a direct connection to the internet.

controls.title: Connecting mobile devices to the internet

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When accessing an organisation system via a VPN connection, split tunnelling is disabled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Labels for TOP SECRET conduits are a minimum size of 2.5 cm x 1 cm, attached at 5 m intervals and marked as ‘TS RUN’.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Conduit labels in areas where uncleared personnel could frequently visit have red text on a clear background.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Conduit labels in areas that are not clearly observable have red text on a white background.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Conduit labels installed in public or visitor areas do not draw undue attention from people who do not have a need-to-know of the existence of such cables.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Wall outlet boxes denote the classification, cable identifiers and wall outlet box identifier.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cables are labelled at each end with sufficient source and destination details to enable the physical identification and inspection of the cable.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A cable labelling process, and supporting cable labelling procedures, is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
A cable register is maintained with the following information:
• cable identifier
• classification
• source
• destination
• site/floor plan diagram
• seal numbers (if applicable).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cables are inspected for inconsistencies with the cable register at least annually.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only approved cable groups terminate on a patch panel.

controls.title: Patch cable and fly lead connectors

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In areas containing cables for systems of different classifications, connectors for each system are different from those of other systems; unless the higher classified patch cables cannot bridge the distance between the higher classified patch panel and any patch panel of a lower classification.

controls.title: Patch cable and fly lead connectors

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In areas containing cables for TOP SECRET systems and systems of lower classifications, the connectors for TOP SECRET systems are different from those of other systems.

controls.title: Patch cable and fly lead connectors

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In areas containing cables for systems of different classifications, the selection of connector types is documented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: TOP SECRET and non-TOP SECRET patch panels are physically separated by installing them in separate cabinets.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Where spatial constraints demand patch panels of lower classifications than TOP SECRET be located in the same cabinet as a TOP SECRET patch panel:
• a physical barrier in the cabinet is provided to separate patch panels
• only personnel holding a Positive Vetting security clearance have access to the cabinet
• approval from the TOP SECRET system’s authorising officer is obtained prior to installation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If fibre-optic fly leads exceeding five meters in length are used to connect wall outlet boxes to ICT equipment, they are run in a protective and easily inspected pathway and clearly labelled at the ICT equipment end with the wall outlet box’s identifier.

controls.title: Emanation security threat assessments in Australia

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System owners deploying systems with Radio Frequency (RF) transmitters inside or co-located with their facility contact the ACSC for an emanation security threat assessment and implement any additional installation criteria derived from the emanation security threat assessment.

controls.title: Emanation security threat assessments in Australia

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System owners deploying systems with RF transmitters that will be co-located with systems of a higher classification contact the ACSC for an emanation security threat assessment and implement any additional installation criteria derived from the emanation security threat assessment.

controls.title: Emanation security threat assessments in Australia

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System owners deploying systems in shared facilities with non-Australian government entities contact the ACSC for an emanation security threat assessment and implement any additional installation criteria derived from the emanation security threat assessment.

controls.title: Emanation security threat assessments outside Australia

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System owners deploying systems overseas contact the ACSC for emanation security threat advice and implement any additional installation criteria derived from the emanation security threat advice.

controls.title: Emanation security threat assessments outside Australia

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System owners deploying systems overseas contact the ACSC for an emanation security threat assessment and implement any additional installation criteria derived from the emanation security threat assessment.

controls.title: Early identification of emanation security issues

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An emanation security threat assessment is sought as early as possible in a project’s life cycle as emanation security controls can have significant cost implications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment in TOP SECRET areas meets industry and government standards relating to electromagnetic interference/electromagnetic compatibility.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cables are installed in accordance with the relevant Australian Standards, as directed by the Australian Communications and Media Authority.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The cable colours in the following table are used (see source document for referenced table).

controls.title: Cable colours for foreign systems in Australian facilities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cable colours for foreign systems installed in Australian facilities are not the same colour as those used for Australian systems.

controls.title: Cable colours for foreign systems in Australian facilities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cable colours used for foreign systems are agreed between the host organisation and the foreign system’s owner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In non-TOP SECRET areas, cables with non-conformant cable colouring are banded with the appropriate colour at inspection points.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In TOP SECRET areas, cables with non-conformant cable colouring are both banded with the appropriate colour and labelled at inspection points.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In non-shared government facilities, cables are inspectable at a minimum of five-metre intervals.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In non-TOP SECRET areas of shared government facilities, cables are inspectable at a minimum of five-metre intervals.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In TOP SECRET areas of shared government facilities, cables are fully inspectable for their entire length.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In non-TOP SECRET areas of shared non-government facilities, cables are inspectable at a minimum of five-metre intervals.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In TOP SECRET areas of shared non-government facilities, cables are fully inspectable for their entire length.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The approved group combinations for cables in the following table are used (see source document for referenced table).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Fibre-optic cables are used for network infrastructure instead of copper cables.

controls.title: Fibre-optic cables sharing a common conduit

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: With fibre-optic cables, the fibres in the sheath only carry a single group.

controls.title: Fibre-optic cables sharing a common conduit

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If a fibre-optic cable contains subunits, each subunit only carries a single group; however, each subunit in the cable can carry a different group.

controls.title: Cables sharing a common reticulation system

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Approved cable groups sharing a common reticulation system have a dividing partition or a visible gap between the differing cable groups.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In shared non-government facilities, cables are run in an enclosed cable reticulation system.

controls.title: Covers for enclosed cable reticulation systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In shared non-government facilities, conduits or the front covers of ducts, cable trays in floors and ceilings, and associated fittings are clear plastic.

controls.title: Sealing cable reticulation systems and conduits

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In shared non-government facilities, uniquely identifiable SCEC endorsed tamper-evident seals are used to seal all removable covers on reticulation systems.

controls.title: Sealing cable reticulation systems and conduits

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In shared non-government facilities, a visible smear of conduit glue is used to seal all plastic conduit joints and conduit runs connected by threaded lock nuts.

controls.title: Connecting cable reticulation systems to cabinets

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In non-TOP SECRET areas, reticulation systems leading into cabinets are terminated as close as possible to the cabinet.

controls.title: Connecting cable reticulation systems to cabinets

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In TOP SECRET areas, reticulation systems leading into cabinets in a secure communications or server room are terminated as close as possible to the cabinet.

controls.title: Connecting cable reticulation systems to cabinets

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In TOP SECRET areas, reticulation systems leading into cabinets not in a secure communications or server room are terminated at the boundary of the cabinet.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cables are terminated in individual cabinets, or for small systems, one cabinet with a division plate to delineate classifications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: TOP SECRET cables are terminated in an individual TOP SECRET cabinet.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: There is a visible gap between TOP SECRET cabinets and cabinets of lower classifications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cables from cable trays to wall outlet boxes are run in flexible or plastic conduit.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In shared non-government facilities, cables are not run in a party wall.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In shared government facilities, where wall penetrations exit into a lower classified space, cables are encased in conduit with all gaps between the conduit and the wall filled with an appropriate sealing compound.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In shared non-government facilities, where wall penetrations exit into a lower classified space, cables are encased in conduit with all gaps between the conduit and the wall filled with an appropriate sealing compound.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cable groups sharing a wall outlet box use fibre-optic cables and different connectors on opposite sides of the wall outlet for each group.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: TOP SECRET cables do not share a wall outlet box with cables of a lower classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The connectors for TOP SECRET systems are different from those of systems of lower classifications.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The wall outlet box colours in the following table are used (see source document for referenced table).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Wall outlet box covers are clear plastic.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When penetrating an audio secured space, ASIO is consulted and all directions provided are complied with.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In TOP SECRET areas of shared government facilities, a power distribution board with a feed from an Uninterruptible Power Supply is used to power all TOP SECRET ICT equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: In TOP SECRET areas of shared non-government facilities, a power distribution board with a feed from an Uninterruptible Power Supply is used to power all TOP SECRET ICT equipment.

controls.title: ICT equipment sanitisation and disposal processes and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An ICT equipment sanitisation process, and supporting ICT equipment sanitisation procedures, is developed and implemented.

controls.title: ICT equipment sanitisation and disposal processes and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An ICT equipment disposal process, and supporting ICT equipment disposal procedures, is developed and implemented.

controls.title: ICT equipment sanitisation and disposal processes and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When disposing of ICT equipment containing media, the ICT equipment is sanitised by sanitising the media within the ICT equipment, removing the media from the ICT equipment or destroying the ICT equipment in its entirety.

controls.title: ICT equipment sanitisation and disposal processes and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Labels and markings indicating the classification, codewords, caveats, owner, system, network, or any other marking that can associate the ICT equipment with its original use, are removed prior to disposal.

controls.title: ICT equipment sanitisation and disposal processes and procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, destruction or declassification, a formal administrative decision is made to handle ICT equipment, or its waste, as ‘publicly releasable’ before it is released into the public domain.

controls.title: Sanitisation and disposal of highly sensitive ICT equipment

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If disposing of high assurance ICT equipment or TEMPEST-rated ICT equipment, the ACSC is contacted for requirements relating to its secure disposal.

controls.title: Sanitisation and disposal of highly sensitive ICT equipment

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment, including associated media, that is located overseas and has processed or stored AUSTEO or AGAO information is sanitised in situ.

controls.title: Sanitisation and disposal of highly sensitive ICT equipment

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment, including associated media, that is located overseas and has processed or stored AUSTEO or AGAO information that cannot be sanitised in situ is returned to Australia for destruction.

controls.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: At least three pages of random text with no blank areas are printed on each colour printer cartridge or MFD print drum.

controls.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: MFD print drums and image transfer rollers are inspected and destroyed if there is remnant toner which cannot be removed or if a print is visible on the image transfer roller.

controls.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Printer and MFD platens are inspected and destroyed if any images are retained on the platen.

controls.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Printers and MFDs are checked to ensure no pages are trapped in the paper path due to a paper jam.

controls.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When unable to sanitise printer cartridges or MFD print drums, they are destroyed as per electrostatic memory devices.

controls.title: Sanitisation and disposal of printers and multifunction devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Printer ribbons in printers and MFDs are removed and destroyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Televisions and computer monitors with minor burn-in or image persistence are sanitised by displaying a solid white image on the screen for an extended period of time.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Televisions and computer monitors that cannot be sanitised are destroyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Memory in network devices is sanitised using the following processes, in order of preference:
• following device-specific guidance provided by the ACSC
• following vendor sanitisation guidance
• loading a dummy configuration file, performing a factory reset and then reinstalling firmware.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The paper tray of the fax machine is removed, and a fax message with a minimum length of four pages is transmitted, before the paper tray is re-installed to allow a fax summary page to be printed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Fax machines are checked to ensure no pages are trapped in the paper path due to a paper jam.

controls.title: Maintenance and repairs of high assurance ICT equipment

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The ACSC’s approval is sought before undertaking any repairs to high assurance ICT equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Maintenance and repairs of ICT equipment is carried out on-site by an appropriately cleared technician.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If an uncleared technician is used to undertake maintenance or repairs of ICT equipment, the ICT equipment and associated media is sanitised before maintenance or repair work is undertaken.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
If an uncleared technician is used to undertake maintenance or repairs of ICT equipment, the technician is escorted by someone who:
• is appropriately cleared and briefed
• takes due care to ensure that information is not disclosed
• takes all responsible measures to ensure the integrity of the ICT equipment
• has the authority to direct the technician
• is sufficiently familiar with the ICT equipment to understand the work being performed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment maintained or repaired off-site is done so in accordance with the physical transfer and storage requirements for the sensitivity or classification of the ICT equipment.

controls.title: Maintenance and repair of ICT equipment from secured spaces

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment maintained or repaired off-site is treated as per the requirements for the sensitivity or classification of the area that the ICT equipment will be returned to.

controls.title: Inspection of ICT equipment following maintenance and repairs

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following maintenance or repair activities for ICT equipment, the ICT equipment is inspected to confirm it retains its approved software configuration and that no unauthorised modifications have taken place.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An ICT equipment management policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment is classified based on the highest sensitivity or classification of information that it is approved for processing, storing or communicating.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment, with the exception of high assurance ICT equipment, is labelled with protective markings reflecting its sensitivity or classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The Australian Cyber Security Centre (ACSC)’s approval is sought before applying labels to external surfaces of high assurance ICT equipment.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment is handled in a manner suitable for its sensitivity or classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An ICT equipment and media register is maintained and regularly audited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All ICT equipment and media are accounted for on a regular basis.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: ICT equipment and media are secured when not in use.

groups.title: Wireless devices and Radio Frequency transmitters

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An authorised RF devices for SECRET and TOP SECRET areas register is maintained and regularly audited.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unauthorised RF devices are not brought into SECRET and TOP SECRET areas.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security measures are used to detect and respond to unauthorised RF devices in SECRET and TOP SECRET areas.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Bluetooth and wireless keyboards are not used unless in an RF screened building.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When using infrared keyboards, infrared ports are positioned to prevent line of sight and reflected communications travelling into an unsecured space.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
When using infrared keyboards, the following activities are prevented:
• line of sight and reflected communications travelling into unsecured spaces
• multiple infrared keyboards for different systems being used in the same area
• other infrared devices being used in the same area
• infrared keyboards operating in areas with unprotected windows.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
When using infrared keyboards, the following activities are prevented:
• line of sight and reflected communications travelling into unsecured spaces
• multiple infrared keyboards for different systems being used in the same area
• other infrared devices being used in the same area
• infrared keyboards operating in areas with windows that have not had a permanent method of blocking infrared transmissions applied to them.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Wireless RF pointing devices are not used in TOP SECRET areas unless used in an RF screened building.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any facility containing a system, including a deployable system, is certified and accredited to at least the sensitivity or classification of the system.

controls.title: Server rooms, communications rooms and security containers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Servers and network devices are secured in server rooms or communications rooms that meet the requirements for a Security Zone or secure room suitable for their sensitivity or classification.

controls.title: Server rooms, communications rooms and security containers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Servers and network devices are secured in lockable commercial cabinets or security containers suitable for their sensitivity or classification taking into account protection afforded by the Security Zone or secure room they reside in.

controls.title: Server rooms, communications rooms and security containers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Server rooms, communications rooms and security containers are not left in unsecured states.

controls.title: Server rooms, communications rooms and security containers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Keys or equivalent access mechanisms to server rooms, communications rooms and security containers are appropriately controlled.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information communicated over network infrastructure in areas not authorised for the processing of such information is encrypted as if it was communicated through unsecured spaces.

controls.title: Controlling physical access to network devices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Physical security controls are implemented to protect network devices, especially those in public areas, from physical damage or unauthorised access.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unauthorised people are prevented from observing systems, in particular, workstation displays and keyboards.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A data transfer process, and supporting data transfer procedures, is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users transferring data to and from a system are held accountable for the data they transfer.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Trusted sources are limited to people and systems that have been authorised as such by an organisation’s CISO.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: All data transferred to a system of a lesser sensitivity or classification is reviewed and approved by a trusted source.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A trusted source signs all data authorised for export from a system.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data imported to a system is scanned for malicious and active content.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data imported to a system is scanned for malicious and active content, undergoes data format checks and logging, and is monitored to detect overuse/unusual usage patterns.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When exporting data, protective marking checks are undertaken.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
When exporting data, the following activities are undertaken:
• protective marking checks
• data format checks and logging
• monitoring to detect overuse/unusual usage patterns
• limitations on data types and sizes
• keyword searches on all textual data.

controls.title: Preventing export of particularly important data to foreign systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A process, and supporting procedures, is developed and implemented to prevent AUSTEO and AGAO data in both textual and non-textual formats from being exported to foreign systems.

controls.title: Preventing export of particularly important data to foreign systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When exporting data from an AUSTEO or AGAO system, keyword searches are undertaken on all textual data and any identified data is quarantined until reviewed and approved for release by a trusted source other than the originator.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data transfer logs are used to record all data imports and exports from systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data transfer logs are partially audited at least monthly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data transfer logs are fully audited at least monthly.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A media destruction process, and supporting media destruction procedures, is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
The following media types are destroyed prior to disposal as they cannot be sanitised:
• microfiche and microfilm
• optical discs
• programmable read-only memory
• read-only memory
• other types of media that cannot be sanitised
• faulty media that cannot be successfully sanitised.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: SCEC or ASIO approved equipment is used when destroying media.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If using degaussers to destroy media, degaussers evaluated by the United States’ National Security Agency are used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Equipment that is capable of reducing microform to a fine powder, with resultant particles not showing more than five consecutive characters per particle upon microscopic inspection, is used to destroy microfiche and microfilm.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: One of the methods in the following table is used to destroy media (see source document for referenced table).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The resulting waste for all destruction methods, except for furnace/incinerator and degausser, is stored and handled as per the following table (see source document for referenced table).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A degausser of sufficient field strength for the coercivity of the magnetic media is used, with the field strength being checked at regular intervals.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A degausser capable of the magnetic orientation (longitudinal or perpendicular) of the magnetic media is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any product-specific directions provided by degausser manufacturers are followed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The destruction of media is performed under the supervision of at least one person cleared to the sensitivity or classification of the media being destroyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel supervising the destruction of media supervise the handling of the media to the point of destruction and ensure that the destruction is completed successfully.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The destruction of accountable material is performed under the supervision of at least two personnel cleared to the sensitivity or classification of the media being destroyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel supervising the destruction of accountable media supervise the handling of the material to the point of destruction, ensure that the destruction is completed successfully and sign a destruction certificate afterwards.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When outsourcing the destruction of media to an external destruction service, a National Association for Information Destruction AAA certified destruction service with endorsements, as specified in ASIO’s PSC-167, is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The destruction of TOP SECRET media or accountable material is not outsourced.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A media management policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A removable media usage policy is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is classified to the highest sensitivity or classification of information stored on the media.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any media connected to a system is classified as the same sensitivity or classification as the system, unless the media is read-only, the media is inserted into a read-only device or the system has a mechanism through which read-only access can be ensured.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is reclassified if information copied onto the media is of a higher sensitivity or classification than the information already on the media, or information stored on the media is subject to a classification upgrade.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If reclassifying media to a lower sensitivity or classification, the reclassification of all information on the media has been approved by the originator, or the media has been appropriately sanitised/destroyed and a formal administrative decision has been made to reclassify it.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media, with the exception of internally mounted fixed media within ICT equipment, is labelled with protective markings reflecting its sensitivity or classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is sanitised before it is used with systems for the first time.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is not used with systems that are not authorised to process, store or communicate the sensitivity or classification of information on it.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any automatic execution features for media are disabled in the operating system of systems.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unauthorised media is prevented from connecting to systems via the use of device access control software, disabling connection ports, or by physical means.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is prevented from being written to via the use of device access control software if there is no business requirement for its use.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is handled in a manner suitable for its sensitivity or classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Media is encrypted with at least an Australian Signals Directorate Approved Cryptographic Algorithm.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: When transferring data manually between two systems belonging to different security domains, write-once media is used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If not using write-once media for transferring data manually between two systems belonging to different security domains, the media is sanitised between each data transfer.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A media disposal process, and supporting media disposal procedures, is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, destruction or declassification, a formal administrative decision is made to handle media, or its waste, as ‘publicly releasable’ before it is released into the public domain.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Labels and markings indicating the classification, codewords, caveats, owner, system, network, or any other marking that can associate media with its original use, are removed prior to disposal.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A media sanitisation process, and supporting media sanitisation procedures, is developed and implemented.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Volatile media is sanitised by removing power from the media for at least 10 minutes or by overwriting all locations on the media with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Volatile media is sanitised by overwriting the media at least once in its entirety with a random pattern, followed by a read back for verification, and then followed by removing power from the media for at least 10 minutes.

controls.title: Treatment of volatile media following sanitisation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, highly classified volatile media retains its classification if it stored static data for an extended period of time, or had data repeatedly stored on or written to the same memory location for an extended period of time.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The host-protected area and device configuration overlay table of non-volatile magnetic media is reset prior to sanitisation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Non-volatile magnetic media is sanitised by booting from separate media to the media being sanitised and then overwriting the media at least once (or three times if pre-2001 or under 15 Gigabytes) in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The ATA secure erase command is used where available, in addition to using block overwriting software, to ensure the growth defects table (g-list) is overwritten.

controls.title: Treatment of non-volatile magnetic media following sanitisation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, highly classified non-volatile magnetic media retains its classification.

controls.title: Non-volatile erasable programmable read-only memory media sanitisation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Non-volatile EPROM media is sanitised by erasing the media in accordance with the manufacturer’s specification, increasing the specified ultraviolet erasure time by a factor of three, then overwriting the media at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

controls.title: Non-volatile electrically erasable programmable read-only memory media sanitisation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Non-volatile EEPROM media is sanitised by overwriting the media at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

controls.title: Treatment of non-volatile erasable and electrically erasable programmable read-only memory media following sanitisation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, highly classified non-volatile EPROM and EEPROM media retains its classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Non-volatile flash memory media is sanitised by overwriting the media at least twice in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

controls.title: Treatment of non-volatile flash memory media following sanitisation

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Following sanitisation, highly classified non-volatile flash memory media retains its classification.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Where a consumer guide for evaluated encryption software exists, the sanitisation and post-sanitisation requirements stated in the consumer guide are followed.

controls.title: Providing cyber security leadership and guidance

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A CISO is appointed to provide cyber security leadership and guidance for their organisation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO oversees their organisation’s cyber security program and ensures their organisation’s compliance with cyber security policy, standards, regulations and legislation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO regularly reviews and updates their organisation’s cyber security program to ensure its relevance in addressing cyber threats and harnessing business and cyber security opportunities.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO implements cyber security measurement metrics and key performance indicators for their organisation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO coordinates cyber security and business alignment through a cyber security steering committee or advisory board, comprising of key business and ICT executives, which meets formally and on a regular basis.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO coordinates security risk management activities between cyber security and business teams.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO reports directly to their organisation’s senior executive and/or Board on cyber security matters.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO is fully aware of all cyber security incidents within their organisation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO oversees their organisation’s response to cyber security incidents.

controls.title: Contributing to business continuity and disaster recovery planning

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO contributes to the development and maintenance of a business continuity and disaster recovery plan for their organisation to ensure that business-critical services are supported appropriately in the event of a disaster.

controls.title: Developing a cyber security communications strategy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO develops and maintains a cyber security communications strategy for their organisation.

controls.title: Working with suppliers and service providers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO oversees cyber supply chain risk management activities for their organisation.

controls.title: Receiving and managing a dedicated cyber security budget

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO receives and manages a dedicated cyber security budget for their organisation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO oversees the management of cyber security personnel within their organisation.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The CISO oversees the development and operation of their organisation’s cyber security awareness training program.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Each system has a designated system owner.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System owners register each system with the system’s authorising officer.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System owners obtain authorisation to operate each system from the system’s authorising officer.

controls.title: Monitoring cyber threats, security risks and security controls

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System owners monitor security risks and the effectiveness of security controls for each system.

controls.title: Annual reporting of system security status

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: System owners report the security status of each system to its authorising officer at least annually.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A review of suppliers and service providers, including their country of origin, is performed before obtaining software, hardware or services to assess the potential increase to an organisation’s security risk profile.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: High risk suppliers and service providers are not used.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Outsourced information technology and cloud services are chosen from service providers that have made a commitment to secure practices and have a strong track record of maintaining the security of their systems and services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Service providers provide an appropriate level of protection for any official, sensitive or classified information entrusted to them or their services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A shared responsibility model is created between service providers and organisations in order to articulate the security responsibilities of each party.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Commercial and government gateway services selected by the ACSC undergo a joint security assessment by ACSC and Information Security Registered Assessors Program (IRAP) assessors at least every 24 months.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cloud service providers and their cloud services undergo a security assessment by an IRAP assessor at least every 24 months.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Only community or private clouds are used for outsourced cloud services.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security requirements associated with the confidentiality, integrity and availability of information entrusted to a service provider are documented in contractual arrangements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The right to audit security controls associated with the protection of information and services is specified in contractual arrangements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Types of information and its ownership is documented in contractual arrangements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The regions or availability zones where information will be processed, stored and communicated is documented in contractual arrangements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to all logs relating to an organisation’s information and services are specified in contractual arrangements.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information entrusted to a service provider is stored in a portable manner that allows organisations to perform backups, service migration or service decommissioning without any loss of information.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A minimum notification period of one month for the cessation of any services by a service provider is documented in contractual arrangements.

controls.title: Access to systems and information by service providers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An organisation’s systems and information are not accessed or administered by a service provider unless a contractual arrangement exists between the organisation and the service provider to do so.

controls.title: Access to systems and information by service providers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: If an organisation’s systems or information are accessed or administered by a service provider in an unauthorised manner, organisations are immediately notified.
